p.s: In chapter 24 narrative perspectives and techniques are used to present Starr's state of mind.
Starr is the protagonist of the novel and tells the whole story out of her perspective.
That is why the point of view is the first person protagonist narrator.
The word I I haven't been back since that night (l. 5) indicates it too.
For the reader it is easy to relate to Starr, because he knows exactly what is going on inside her head.
The reader gets also emotionally involved.
When Starr arrives at the street where Khalil got shot, Starr gets flashbacks.

Through the flashbacks Khalil drops it into the side of the door (l. 19), he opens the door to ask if I'm okay (l. 21) and then pow-pow (l. 22) the reader gets a closer look at what Starr is thinking about.
The reader also gets sympathetic, because she is going through the whole situation again.
Interior monologue is often used in this novel, especially when Starr has a conflict with herself.
For example when she stands on the patrol car with the bullhorn, wants to speak out, but does not know what to say Shit, I have no idea what to say(l. 44).
But she knows that she needs to speak up so she says to herself You know what?Fuck it (l. 58).
This presents her state of mind very well, because the reader knows exactly which thoughts are going through her brain.
This whole situation is presented in scenic mode, which means that a situation is described in very detail.
The direct speech A hairbrush is not a gun(l. 8), which is also a narrative technique, indicates that it is written in very detail.
But also phrases like ahead of the crowd a lady with twists stands on top of a police car, holding a bullhorn (l. 10) show that the reader gets to know every detail.
It makes him feel like he is in the situation right now too and so he can relate to Starr's thoughts more.
To sum it all up, once can say that through these narrative techniques the reader gets a closer look at Starr's thoughts and her state of mind.
